description: Looks nice but doesn't work for me, constantly has issues with playback, when no o ther media player does.

MPV is a really great player and together with VLC the golden standard. Celluloid plays everything I throw at it, is easy to use and looks very good on my GNOME desktop. The only Media Player you will ever need!

It looks very simple and minimal on the outside, but it has many features as keyboard shortcuts...while this may help it look less cluttery, it's hard to remember all the shortcuts, or check them each time you wanna perform something...
Better than MPV though...that was too barebones
Drag and drop does not work from some apps (like doublecommander). Ctrl+c.... closes the player. Also does not play all vidoe formats as other players do.
Needs more advanced features from mainstream

Good options.
Perfect
when i open the app it freezes and then closes
summary: does not run on debian 10 buster

description: working"""!!!!!
It cannot ope directory and play media from that.
NEEDS a lot of options to be versatile enough

The video breaks in horizontal segments when playing videos.
I suspect it is due to some issue with VSYNC.
Can be recreated in the ubuntu 20.04 in normal ubuntu xorg display manager and issue is most observable when the video pans ie the scenes where camera is moving
summary: THere is very bad vsync issue

description: I love the minimalistic interface of the app but really love to see options for changing subtitle font size and the font family in general inside the app settings in gui instead of me having to write mpv conf file and load that.
summary: The best video player for linux

description: Found pure mpv UI does not display well , but Celluloid fixed it !
best video player tool
You want this app if you run the Gnome desktop. Heck, you probably want this app on LXDE or KDE too! Absolutely excellent.
summary: Excellent, way better than standard Gnome Videos

description: I really love its simplicity. It works as expected. No problems.
Forward and backward rewind with arrow keys is consistent, unlike Videos.
summary: What GNOME Videos should have been

description: A simple video player which can by playing any Quality or Format. Just need some more Advance Options.
Great and clean UI

This app, when installed from flatpak, fails to open files that are not local. For example: ssh:///mnt/movies/some_movie.mp4
These same files open just fine in VLC.
summary: Fails to open non local files without error

description: nice video player
TErminated abnormaly
better then VLC

I was new on linux & struggled in almost everything... After using CELLULOID/GNOME MPV I became a dedicated linux user.... It is very light yet extremely powerful & user friendly.... I always adjust visuals throught dedicated shortcuts.... & this unique feature is specially blessing for me

both MPV and VLC are playing x264 encodes reasonably well but HEVC (x265/h265/AV1) is still too very resource intensive and video is choppy sometimes. 
where is my Librem 5 AV1 iGPU decoding ?

This is probably my favorite, and one of the best MPV front ends. It integrates with GNOME really nicely, and is very user friendly.

My only complaint is when in fullscreen mode and I need to adjust some controls the headerbar reappears and gets in the way of some of the video.

Another useless player. There is no way for a non-technical user (meaning someone who doesn't have a computer science doctorate) to configure audio playback with a USB audio interface. Most controls for necessary functions were removed or are hidden from the user . No documentation, either. All software is so BAD anymore!!!

It does extremely efficiently.... Best audio output..... Video adoptive works are rendered without any load on system.... It smoothly runs video that other players can't without lagging....
Just One problem """Opening a folder in Celluloid from from menu options of Nautilus can't load files'''' Hope will be fixed soon...
working almost perfect
MPV better than VLC
Good app. Love the simplicity.
Fast and light, I love it
After figuring out where the configuration file is, it does not work.
Doesn't play back video

This is an excellent player, except it totally locks up the system occasionally (I'm using 21.04). When this happens it requires a reboot of Ubuntu. So for now I have to uninstall, and hope someday it gets fixed.
Was using VLC for ages then found this. I prefer. Simple to use and plays everything.
I think it's better than VLC. No need to configure anything - just works.
Linux people are obsessed with weird names, but the app does the job. Looks prettier than VLC and plays well with GNOME desktop.
Great for looping videos seamlessly.
Even after manually enabling the setting in the config
WHY I CANT HAVE IT BLAH BLAH

Almost what I need, missing just a few settings.

I suggest to install it via dnf, cause flatpak messes things up
i tried many different videos, but celluloid refuses to use my nvidia decoder like vlc does.
summary: no accelerated decoding, pretty much useless

description: Works flawlessly on some videos that are glitching out like crazy on VLC ever since I installed my new video card. And unlike a lot of other 'simple' video players, it has all the basic controls. Just wish it had user-settable keyboard shortcuts.
It integrates quite well with the gnome de. However hardware acceleration needs to be enabled manually in the flatpak version.

I think we gotta have more video players in addition to Vlc. Vlc have many problems I remove that and after few hours looking for a vlc alternative I found this and this has all thing that I want. It's simple, beautiful and you can see a Gnome style UI.

Couldn't find a way to enable hwdec by default other then to load a config file. It would have been better if the app generted the config files it self based on the settings I could have provided through the GUI

It could've been a great app but sometimes it crashes.
I wish it had visual feature like rotate, brightness, etc.

I'm using Celluloid on Fedora 35. Tried the default Gnome Videos, but that wasn't great for watching shows as it wouldn't play the next episode when one ended. Switched to the old trusty VLC, but had some issues with video not showing until 30 seconds into a file. Tried a handful of others until I found Celluloid. I've been using it for a couple of weeks now and haven't had one issue with it. There's not a single thing about the program that I would change. It's exactly what I was looking for in a video player. Highly recommend.

I want to love it, because mpv is great but maybe a little too sparse on its own, so this should be a perfect and nice-looking alternative to VLC. Problem is (on Fedora 36/Wayland/Nvidia, either as flatpak or from rpmfusion) videos freeze the minute you try to seek. The GUI also becomes unresponsive. The audio continues to play, but the entire interface becomes completely frozen. It seems like you can still go fullscreen, but the window doesn't actually move or change appearance. I'd gladly overlook a few rough edges for a nice simple, clean, user-friendly video player; unfortunately, in its current state, this isn't actually usable, at least on my machine.

No stuttering. I wish it had more features like VLC.

– Torin Doyle
the best video player

It is only browser that runs all vids with efficiency... Yet it has some limitations... There is no good options for making and accessing playlists... Can't play anything from Trash, & also has problems with folder selection...

Great little Gnome media give a good feature set without recording history or any of the other privacy concerns of other players based around Video playlist and archive's. Some time you just want a simple to use product that does what it says on the tin well. This has always since I started out on Debian my go to Media player, and on Fedora 36 still is. That said is F36 / Kernel 5.18 I have crashes mostly running big playists. But a lot changed in Gnome 42 and it did break this app but the team of dev's work well and fixed the theming issue brought on by new GTK4 and Libadwaita changes. I use the flat pack so it installs the things needed to run different Video codac's as of yet I haven't found a Video format I can't play in it. While Gnome Player it not gone in a direction that I think is beneficial. yplayer is still to becsic. So for me bugs included this is my daily media viewer.

I love how it works for all video file types I have tried and it is not laggy. I would wish it would remember the last point a file was paused or stopped but I don't know if that would affect how well it works.
Just core dumps when I launch it.
summary: Core dump before I can do anything

description: simply the best

Cannot confiure it to use YOUR choice of keys. Refuses to let you navigate to where your config files are on the disk. This is why people hate linux. Everything is made too complicated and you need a uni degree to change a simple key mapping.
Minimalistic interface in Ubuntu, stable work, correct play mp4 files (VLC makes double windows? control in ine and moovie in second). Like it!
highly recomment using
summary: nice app, better than any video players

description: works really well, love the ui
In many ways, even better than vanilla mpv
A lot more clean and sleek than VLC, works great on Ubuntu.
my default video player
Works great on Ubuntu 22.10, fitting aesthetic too! There's could be some improvement though. For example, the hide mouse feature doesn't work on windowed mode.

easy to install and usable out of the box.
No need to compile mpv yourself and deal with compilation problems anymore!
It can use nvidia decoder "nvdec" for hardware decoding, which is why I chose to use mpv in the first place to play av1 codec smoothly.
I recommend to try it out, u will not regret it
Fast , Light weight , simple UI ... This is perfect
summary: Fast , Light weight , simple UI ... This is perfect

description: Very nice and fast with simple for use
the only player that can play ts video files without stuttering

Works perfect but would like to not need two clicks to change the loudness and too many clicks to change the sound track for MKV files.

VLC does that better, but Celluloid has otherwise great UI.

I recently tried out the Celloid video player on my Linux system and I have to say, I'm really impressed. It works flawlessly and I love its user-friendly interface. The playback is smooth and the video quality is excellent. The controls are easy to use and I appreciate the fact that it supports a wide range of video file formats.

Overall, I would highly recommend the Celloid video player for anyone looking for a reliable and efficient video player on Linux. It works fine and I love it!
summary: It works fine. I love it

description: Needs updated controls for deb version and touch support
summary: Deb player is great Flatpak doesnt work

description: This is unstable and any dvd movies won't work at all
summary: I'm very disappointed for this software

description: Open Celluloid on ubuntu software and click permissions. Enable Read/Write permissions. Now you can play videos from other sources and drives.

I can't do a bad review just because other media player are worse. It's just a mpv wrapper (and that's why works well). 

Improvments:
- use a monospace font for the video timing. (It moves the seekbar)
- fix the bug where you can't use the hamburger menu in fullscreen more than once. (to understand it, try to change audio track two times while fullscreen)
- Don't relay only on keyboard shortcuts. It would be nice to change speed with UI. A window menu could show all the other options grafically (like video colours, caption settings etc..)

Arch Linux on wayland. Flatpak package.

thast greate
its so quickly
MPV plays a video. Celluloid does not. Useless.

It used to be a good player before wayland. Now it has a couple of issues including

- lost of sync between audio and video
- audio cracking miserably
- video stuttering
Even after installing "necessary" codecs, it still would not play purchased DVDs.

Doesn't play sound anymore on my Steam Deck so I'm using another app.
No, not an unverified Flathub app like this one but actually a verified one called "Clapper" made by Rafał Dzięgiel. @rafostar on GitHub.

Devs, I love you but I really need a functioning(with sound) video player and Clapper is that
summary: You broke this app on Steam Deck stable

description: I wanted a native looking GTK app that can play h.265 files out of the box. VLC is the last option I would prefer (cause the native UI is alien to GNOME desktop) if nothing works. But thankfully found this gem of a video player which also looks totally at home in GNOME. Thanks devs for this awesome piece of software.
summary: One of the best VLC replacement in GNOME desktop

description: For whatever reason, it shows this as the default program to play MP3s. Didn't work, I installed Lollypop.
i love it because very simple
Simple and it does what it's supposed to
powerful, intuitive (mostly), and just works
Even better with this interface
Very good for use, thanks developers.
Simple and more than sufficient for needs.

Works well, and has nice design, but unlike VLC it has very simple GUI controls which in my opinion is the point of a GUI for mpv. I wish there was a cheatsheet or a hint built-in (you could toggle it by a button), or a possibility to add more complex menus if you want to.
A nice frontend to MPV, withouth extra fuzz. It plays movies IF you have installed the proper codecs. Also, remember to use flat seal in order to enable GPU support, or else Celluloid won't work.
"Hoppla! Es ist etwas schiefgegangen" ist alles, was diese App produziert. Ds oist wirklich gelungen. Ud so irre witzig. Toll!
Guter Medienspieler wenn man die zusätzlichen Funktionen von VLC nicht braucht
Stabil, reaktionsschnell, elegant, sehr gut.

Sehr gute Alternative zu VLC.
Läuft unter Ubuntu stabiler als VLC und ist zu meinem Standardwiedergabeporgramm geworden.

Ich schaue hiermit jegliche Art von Videos und auch TV-Streams gibt er sauber nach ein paar Einträgen* in der mpv.conf wieder. 

*
rtsp-transport=udp
deinterlace
und ein ziemlich gutes Abspielgerät für alle möglichen und 'unmöglichen' Videodateien. Bin sehr zufrieden und habe auch schon in Ubuntu 20 nachgerüstet. Gratulation an die Macher!
summary: Celluloid in Linux Mint 20.3 fest intergriert

description: cumple su función
demasiado minimalista...
simple, sin problema, hermosa, minimal.
Si comme moi vous utilisez VLC mais que vous ne vous servez pas de 80% de ses fonctionnalités, alors Celluloid est parfait !
Pourquoi ce n'est pas par défaut sur plus de systèmes? Fait beaucoup mieux que Parole ou Totem (le lecteur de GNOME)
simple mais efficace il y a tout ce qu'il faut,fonctionne très bien avec xubuntu 20.04

ce n'est pas a mon habitude mais je dois bien avouer que ce coup ci, je ne peux pas trouver de point positif pour mon évaluation... ce n'est pas bien grave, j'utilise MPV pour certain encodage que VLC ne prend pas mais bon... il ne faut pas blâmer les développeur pour autant
S'intègre bien à gnome et permet de lire tous les formats de fichiers que j'ai pu essayer
Je n'arrivais pas à ouvrir mes vidéos et grace à cette appli je peux apprésent les ouvrir rapidement et facilement.

Может быть это только у меня, но... При закрытии вкладки параметры размеры окна видео если оно на весь экран сбрасываются до минимального. Также не пролистываются покадрово форматы отличные от mpeg4, то есть: mpeg2, mov... При нажатии кнопки листать покадрово, перекидывает назад на 5 секунд, если нажимать назад кадры и стопорится. т.е. больше не работает, пока не перезагрузишь видео. Установлены все библиотеки с how to рпмфюжн сайта. Не помогает. Может дело в компьютере, точно не могу сказать: i5 3 поколения и gtx 950. А так плеер неплох и прост, много настроек. Но если бы починить, то было бы идеально. Обновление бы.
Можно загружать списком через контекстное меню или перетаскивать.
Воспроизводит папку целиком. Ничего лишнего или навязчивого. Всё под рукой.
summary: Помогает работать, не требует внимания к себе
